newsitem.title: USA: General Motors says progress made with UAW.
newsitem.headline: General Motors says progress made with UAW.

text.p: General Motors Corp said Monday it has made significant progress in contract talks with the United Auto Workers and is committed to continuing the negotiations.
In a written statement in response to comments made by UAW president Stephen Yokich, GM's vice president of personnel Gerald Knechtel said the talks have been constructive.
"We have had open and constructive dialogue with the UAW since these talks began and have made significant progress on many of the issues," Knechtel said.
Earlier, Yokich said he was disappointed with the talks, which recessed at 0300 EST/0800 GMT Monday. The union's deadline for an agreement had been midnight.
Negotiators were in discussions for about 17 hours on Sunday and early Monday in an attempt to agree on a new contract for about 215,000 UAW members working at GM's U.S. facilities.
Yokich said talks may resume later Monday, and Knechtel said the company remains committed to negotiations.
"We are committed to continuing the dialogue and resolving the remaining issues with the UAW," Knechtel said.
